_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Applicable building, electrical, and plumbing codes.  The facility complies with the Iowa Fertilizer Law
_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: We utilize those portions of these codes which are deemed applicable by the jurisdictional authority
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vandalism/Theft (methamphetamine) provisions have been made to install a protective barrier around the plant perimeter to reduce the potential of vehicular damage
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: flow limiters (what the trade calls an excess flow valve) breakaway couplers have been installed at the risers and a remote emergency shutoff valve at the storage tank
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Regular plant inspection/routine preventive maintenance and repairs
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: pumps, pump seals and piping, plumbing and electrical equipment, and safety equipment.  The breakaway couplers, relief valves, and hoses are also inspected and replaced as necessary

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE AT COOPERATIVE ELEVATOR ASSOCIATION, OCHEYDAN, IOWA.

This facility complies with ANSI Standard K-61.1-1989 requirements with amendments for Anhydrous Ammonia storage. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal, State, and local regulations. If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to immediately notify the Ocheyedan Volunteer Fire Department (via a 911 call) and request that it respond to the emergency. Incidental to the notification to the fire department, a call to the Osceola County, Iowa LEPC (Region 3 Emergency Planning District) will be made.

While we have planned for an emergency, it is acknowledged that a real emergency will be unexpected and may very well be much different and cannot be ensured to duplicate what may have be planned. In reality, the situation that develops may not happen in the manner in which it has been planned. In that event, what may have been planned will serve only as a guideline to follow.

The Emergency Action Plan for this facility describes certain procedures that are intended to minimize the hazards associated with human health and the environment from fires, explosions, the sudden and unexpected release of chemicals (i.e., Anhydrous Ammonia), tornadoes, bomb threats or other accidents or acts of God which might occur on our premises.

The primary emergency coordinator for the Ocheyedan, Iowa location is Greg Atherton, location manager. His work and 24-hour emergency response telephone numbers are provided in the Registration Section of this document. In addition, the following individuals (with associated work and 24-hour emergency response telephone numbers) are to be contacted in order:

                      Greg Atherton, location manager
                               WORK:    (712) 758-3621
                               24-Hour:  (712) 461-1989 (cell)
                               Home:     (712) 758-3427

                      Dave Muilenberg, operations

Work:      (712) 754-2526

                      Robert Jacobs,  general manager

DESCRIPTION OF THE ANHYDROUS AMMONIA STORAGE/DISTRIBUTION PLANT AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED AT COOPERATIVE ELEVATOR ASSOCIATION, OCHEYEDAN, IOWA:

This facility is a bulk anhydrous ammonia storage and distribution plant. The anhydrous ammonia that is stored at  this facility is distributed to agricultural crop producers in the surrounding area who utilize the anhydrous ammonia for crop nutrient purposes. 

The system consists of four (4) storage tanks with associated piping, valves, liquid pump(s), and other miscellaneous equipment. From time-to-time throughout the year numerous portable nurse tanks may also be present at the site. The anhydrous ammonia plant is only operated on a seasonal basis (Spring and Fall). Full-time equivalent employee numbers were computed on that basis. At a maximum, the plant operates a total of three months (1/4 of the year). The FTEs for this company location is three (3).

THE WORST-CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS:

The worst-case scenario is the failure of the largest capacity storage tank when filled to the greatest amount allowed resulting in the release of the total volume of product in a gaseous form. According to EPA's RMP*Comp Program (Version 1.06), the distance to the endpoint is 4.4 miles.

The alternative release scenario involves the transport delivery vehicle pulling away from the intake lines into the storage plant without disconnecting the transfer hoses. The resulting release, according to EPA's RMP*Comp Program has a distance to endpoint of 0.1 miles.

The system is protected by internal ex

ent that the Ocheyedan Fire Department is unable to adequately respond to an emergency at our Ocheyedan location, the Volunteer Fire Department with whom Ocheyedan has a reciprocal agreement will be summoned.  We have discussed this policy with the fire department and Osceola County LEPC (Region 3 Emergency Planning District). Members of the fire department and the LEPC have inspected our anhydrous ammonia plant. In addition, copies of photographs taken of our plant have been provided (for reference) to both entities.

There are four (4) propane storage tanks situated across the street from the anhydrous plant. At the current time propane has been exempted from Risk Management Planning. However, we have considered the impact of a catastrophic release from either propane facility on our anhydrous ammonia plant.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

The plan is to minimize those hazards to human health and to the environment that are associated with accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. Employees working at the bulk storage plant make routine observations prior to and during transfer operations of the anhydrous ammonia from the storage vessel(s) to nurse tanks. In so doing, they are able to detect problems before they arise. This routine inspection identifies any portion of the system which may be under stress or about to fail. Repairs can be made before they become problematic. Employees are annually trained to recognize the hazards associated with storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia. In addition to annual training for employees who have been on the job for a number of years, the company conducts training for new hires. This training includes classroom instruction, on-site training at the plant, and follow-up observation to determine their individual comprehension and understanding of the new hire. Finally, the company routinely invites  local fire department personnel to visit the site. In the event that the local fire department requests assistance in trai

ning its employees on anhydrous ammonia, the company cooperates fully in their endeavors.

In addition to the evaluation of the anhydrous ammonia plant at this site, an evaluation was also made of the potential effects of a release at one of the two (2) propane supply tanks at this site. One tank is situated approximately 200 feet diagonally across the street to the southwest from the anhydrous plant. The second vessel is situated approximately 146 feet south of the anhydrous plant across the street. As indicated in the process description for anhydrous ammonia, employees working at the propane plants also make routine observations of the propane plant. Through their inspection process they can detect potential problems before they become problematic. Employees involved with propane operations are also trained on a routine basis. The company has begun the industry-sponsored CETP training program for its employees. Local agencies, including the fire department has been invited to visit this site.

cess flow valves, check valves, relief valves, manual shut-off valves, and emergency shut-off valves. The loadout risers used in filling nurse tanks are protected by breakaway couplers designed to immediately stop the flow of ammonia if the line or a hose breaks. All of the main storage tank valves are locked when not in use.

Since this facility is located in relatively close proximity to the Town of Ocheyedan,  provisions have been designed to notify all affected persons. An evacuation plan is in place.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:

This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule and all applicable State and local codes and regulations. The anhydrous ammonia system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with ANSI Standard K-61.1-1989 with amendments and State law. 

In addition the company has specific operating procedures in place intended to minimize the potential for an accidental (and potentially catastrophic) release of anhydrous ammonia. Finally, Cooperative Elevator Association has extended to the Ocheyedan Volunteer Fire Department the opportunity to visit our anhydrous ammonia plant, to participate in mock emergency simulation training, and to avail themselves of specific anhydrous ammonia health hazard information and training provided by the company.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

Cooperative Elevator Association, Ocheyedan, Iowa has not experienced any  accidental release involving anhydrous ammonia in the last five years  that caused death, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations or shelterings in place.

THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:

In the event of an emergency involving our anhydrous ammonia system, it is the policy of Cooperative Elevator Association  to immediately notify the Ocheyedan Volunteer Fire Department and the Osceola County, Iowa (Region 3 Emergency Planning District) LEPC to request that they respond to the emergency.
